acquisition_source.description:
:MARC: ``541``

Only the first source is stored: if the record later gets enriched with
metadata coming from a second source, the `acquisition_source` is not
updated.

datetime.description:
:MARC: ``541__d``

This does not necessarily coincide with the creation date of the
record, as there might be some delay between the moment the
original information is obtained and a record is finally created in
the system.
datetime.title: Date on which the metadata was obtained

email.description:
:MARC: ``541__b``

This only gets populated when `method` is `submitter`.
email.title: Email address associated to the submitter's account

internal_uid.description:
:MARC: ``541__a`` with ``inspire:uid:`` prefix.

This only gets populated when `method` is `submitter`.
internal_uid.title: Inspire user ID of the submitter

method.description:
Possible values are:

`submitter`
    when obtained from a user submission. In this case, `orcid`,
    `internal_uid` and `email` store identifiers of the submitter,
    and `submission_number` an ID of the submission.

`oai`
    when obtained by OAI-PMH harvesting.

`batchuploader`
    when obtained through the batch uploader.

`hepcrawl`
    when obtained from a hepcrawl crawler. In this case, `source`
    stores the publisher or the repository that was crawled.

`beard`
    when created after author disambiguation
method.title: How the medata was obtained

anyOf.description:
This identifier is assigned to any curated author record (HEPNAMES on
legacy).  It is mainly used by large collaborations (providing an
`authors.xml` file) to uniquely identify the authors of their articles.
anyOf.title: Inspire ID

anyOf.description:
The BAI (BibAuthorID) is based on the name of the author and is used as
a human-friendly unique identifier. Its general form is a
``firstnames.lastnames.number``, where ``firstnames`` is a list of
first names (or initials) separated by dots, and similarly for
``lastnames``. Only ASCII letters (without diacritics), numbers, dashes
and apostrophes are allowed in the names. By default, only initials of
first names are used, but this may be changed at a cataloguer's
discretion in order to disambiguate otherwise homonymous authors.

.. note::

    This identifier is not persistent, as it can be renamed to become
    more explicit (e.g. transforming an initial into a full name), or
    disappear when merging two different authors.
anyOf.title: Inspire BAI

anyOf.description:
`ORCID <http://orcid.org>`_ provides an identifier for individuals to
use with their name as they engage in research, scholarship, and
innovation activities.

The ORCID identifier can be resolved by prepending ``http://orcid.org``
to the `value`, in order to get the ORCID record of the person.
anyOf.title: ORCID

value.description:
A page name on the English Wikipedia, i.e. the ``Page_name``
part in http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Page_name.

:example: ``Albert_Einstein``

Non-English Wikipedia pages can be referenced by prepending the language.

:example: ``it:Fabiola_Gianotti``

A twitter handle, often preceded by ``@``.

:example: ``Prof_S_Hawking``

Identifier of Linkedin profile, i.e. the part after
``linkedin.com/in/`` in the URL.

:example: ``kylecranmer``

name.description:
:MARC: ``701__a``

The full name of the advisor, written in the
standard ``last names, first names`` form.

:example: ``Smith, John P.S.``

arxiv_categories.description: :MARC: ``65017a`` when it contains an arXiv category.

items.description:
A category that currently exists on arXiv. Note that some categories have
been renamed and are not in this list.  These are taken from the `arXiv API
documentation
<https://arxiv.org/help/api/user-manual#subject_classifications>`_.

:example: ``math.FA`` instead of its previous name, ``funct-an``

arxiv_categories.title: List of research areas of author

awards.title: List of awards received by the author

control_number.description:
:MARC: ``001``

Read-only field. Also called ``record ID`` or ``recid``.
control_number.title: ID of current record

deleted.title: Whether this record has been deleted

deleted_records.description:
:MARC: ``981__a``

List of records that were deleted because they were replaced by
this one. This typically happens when merging two records: one of
them gets enriched with the information of the other one, which is
then superfluous and gets deleted.

For the opposite concept, see :ref:`new_record`.

hidden.description:
:MARC: if ``true``, the email comes from ``371``, if
    ``false``, from ``595``.

Email addresses might be considered sensitive
information and hidden at the user's request.
hidden.title: Whether this address should be hidden

items.description:
:MARC: ``65017`` with ``2:INSPIRE``

The Inspire category (also called field category) classifies the subject
this record is related to.  This classification schema is similar to the
arXiv one (see `elements/arxiv_categories.json`) and there is a way to map
from arXiv categories to Inspire categories.

native_names.description:
Native names of the author, not using the Latin alphabet.

:example: ``楼 立洋``
:MARC: ``880__a``

preferred_name.description:
differs from the full name in `value`. This should use Latin alphabet.

:example: ``Smith, John``
:MARC: ``100__q``

previous_names.description:
Contains previous names of the author, e.g. the maiden
name.

:example: ``Taylor, Jonathan Gerald C.T.``
:MARC: no field for this, was put into ``667__a`` as a note.
previous_names.title: List of previous names

value.description:
Author name in Latin alphabet (may contain diacritics). The
format should be ``last names, first names``. If not all
names are known, initials should be followed by a `.`
without space.

.. note::

    Not all authors have two names, so only one name
    without a comma is perfectly valid.

    :example: ``Jimmy``

:example: ``Smith Davis, Jonathan Gerald C.T.``
:MARC: ``100__a``
